name: Vacuum Hardware Test Plan
description: Automated electrical measurements for vacuums: motor current draw, power consumption, battery voltage under load, charging current, discharge rate
safetyWarnings: Ensure GFCI protection for corded vacuums
For cordless models, check battery for swelling before testing
Do NOT short battery terminals during voltage measurement
Keep hands clear of brush roll during motor tests

steps.name: Motor Current Draw
steps.description: Measure motor current at normal operating speed. Excessive current may indicate worn bearings, clogged filter, or motor winding damage.
steps.setupInstructions: Clamp current clamp around power cord conductor. Turn on vacuum at normal power setting. Allow 5 seconds for motor to stabilize.

steps.name: Power Consumption
steps.description: Measure total power consumption during operation. Compare to rated wattage.
steps.setupInstructions: Connect vacuum through power meter. Turn on at maximum power. Record after 10 seconds of stable operation.

steps.name: Battery Voltage Under Load
steps.description: Measure battery voltage while vacuum motor is running. Voltage sag > 20% indicates degraded battery.
steps.setupInstructions: For cordless vacuums only. Connect multimeter probes to battery terminals. Turn on vacuum and measure while motor is running. Skip for corded models.

steps.name: Charging Current
steps.description: Measure current flowing into battery during charging. No current indicates charger or battery fault.
steps.setupInstructions: For cordless vacuums only. Place on charger. Clamp current clamp around charger cable. Record current after 30 seconds.

steps.name: Battery Discharge Rate
steps.description: Measure voltage drop rate over 60 seconds of operation. Rapid discharge indicates end-of-life battery.
steps.setupInstructions: For cordless vacuums only. Measure battery voltage at start, then after 60 seconds of continuous operation. Voltage drop should be < 15%.
